item.title: SMU and Alibaba Cloud introduce groundbreaking upskilling program beyond China for the first time
item.description: Singapore Management University (SMU) and Alibaba Cloud have teamed up to introduce a series of courses designed to enhance the skills of over 1,000 working professionals in Singapore. This joint initiative, known as the SMU-Alibaba Series, marks Alibaba Cloud’s first professional continuing education program outside of China. Set to commence in March 2019, the program will be delivered through SMU Academy, the university’s professional training division. With a specific focus on empowering small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs), the Series aims to equip businesses with the necessary competencies to navigate the challenges posed by rapid technological advancements and evolving consumer behavior.

item.title: Learn about data science quickly with CEG Digital's online course
item.description: CEG Digital, the flexible learning branch of global education provider Cambridge Education Group (CEG), has teamed up with the Web Science Institute at the University of Southampton (WSI), a top-100 university, to offer short online courses. Dr. Elena Simperl, WSI Associate Professor and Scientific Director of the European Data Science Academy, emphasized the importance of data science skills, stating, “Data science is crucial for our economy. Our new series of short professional courses complement our postgraduate degrees and target decision-makers, business analysts, IT developers, and others interested in cutting-edge data science technologies and applications in fields like digital marketing, finance, and healthcare.

item.title: IBM has raised concerns about the skills gap in India
item.description: Source: IBM. Cover for the Upskilling India report. IBM has released a study conducted by the IBM Institute for Business Value (IBV), in partnership with the Economist Intelligence Unit. This study assesses India’s increasing skills gap and offers suggestions to address the issue. The study surveyed Indian executives, and most believe that the Indian workforce’s skills are on par with or better than those of other nations. However, only 40% reported that new employees possess the necessary skills.
